awd_abstract_narration:
In interpreting linguistic utterances, the human mind has to piece together many different types of information. While this takes place sub-consciously, language researchers have developed theoretical perspectives on how distinct aspects of meaning are factored into the overall interpretation. However, little remains known about how these theoretical constructs relate to actual cognitive processes taking place in real-time. The present project will help to fill this gap by investigating aspects of meaning, specifically presuppositions, with experimental tools from psychology, and thereby deepen our understanding of a fundamental aspect of human interaction. This is essential for a comprehensive perspective on how speakers relate to the world through language, and also bears on broader issues in society. For example, research on the psychology of memory has shown that the presuppositional status of information has strong effects on memory accuracy, which is highly relevant in eye witness testimony and other related activities.
 
With the support of the National Science Foundation, Dr. Schwarz will study how presuppositions relate to other aspects of meaning, such as asserted content and certain pragmatic inferences (specifically implicatures), using a variety of experimental methods. Presuppositions are backgrounded relative to the main point asserted by an utterance, and (typically) already count as established in the discourse. For example, 'again' in 'John left again' suggests that it was already known that John had left previously, the main news being his second departure. The project will investigate the relative time-course of these two aspects of meaning in online processing: Does the presupposition get evaluated first, suggesting that its role for the overall felicity of an utterance needs to be confirmed at the outset? Or does it play the role of an additional inference that is only considered later? Another crucial feature of presuppositions concerns their relation to operators like negation: 'John hasn't left again' still conveys that he left before (while denying a second departure). The project will investigate whether such embedded occurrences of presuppositional expressions introduce additional cognitive demands. Finally, the project will also study the availability and potential cognitive cost of an alternative interpretation of such sentences, as in 'John (certainly) hasn't left again--he never left in the first place!' The present project constitutes the first comprehensive attempt to use tools from experimental psycho-linguistics to study the cognitive processes involved in presupposition comprehension. Using an eye tracker, Dr. Schwarz will record people's eye movements relative to a visual scene while they're hearing linguistic stimuli that contain presuppositional expressions. This allows for real-time insights into the unfolding of individual aspects of the overall meaning with millisecond-accuracy. Response times and other behavioral measures further help to understand speakers' interpretation processes and preferences. By combining theoretical work with foundations in philosophy of language and formal semantics with experimental methods from psycho-linguistics, this interdisciplinary project will help to integrate the study of meaning in natural language more deeply into the cognitive sciences and advance our theoretical and empirical understanding of the human mind's remarkable capacities at work in linguistic communication.

por.por_cntn:
In interpreting linguistic utterances, the human mind has to piece together many different types of information. While much of this takes place sub-consciously, linguists have developed theories of how distinct aspects of meaning are factored into the overall interpretation. However, there has been relatively little prior work on how these theoretical constructs relate to real-time cognitive processes. This project contributed to filling this gap by investigating specific aspects of meaning, focusing on presuppositions, with experimental tools from psycholinguistics. This helped to advance the emerging field of experimental semantics and pragmatics and promote interdisciplinary work by developing a thoroughly empirically based perspective on theoretical questions in the formal study of meaning, deepening our understanding of a fundamental aspect of human interaction.

At the theoretical core of the project, our research aimed at better understanding the properties of presuppositional information, as well as the cognitive processes involved when computing this information. One core property of presuppositions is that they introduce backgrounded information: In ‘John sneezed again’, the presupposition contributed by ‘again’ (roughly, that John sneezed before), is treated as taken for granted. While one could imagine this backgrounded nature to lead to slower or later processing, we find immediate reflexes of it in eye-tacking studies. A second central issue concerned presuppositions in embedded environments, e.g., under negation (as in `John didn’t sneeze again’), which generally still give rise to the same inference (that John sneezed before). We find that processing presuppositions is slower here, but still part of the automatic, incremental interpretation process. Furthermore, we confirmed the existence of alternative interpretation where the presupposition is interpreted relative to negation (`… because he didn’t sneeze before in the first place!’), although these are slower and more effortful. In addition, presuppositional expressions vary in the extent to which they allow these (e.g., ‘stop’ does so more easily than ‘again’), and we find evidence for parallel differences across various embedding contexts (e.g., under quantifiers). At the same time, the profile of these interpretations was experimentally differentiated from superficially parallel-seeming effects for other language-based inferences (such as implicatures). The last central issue concerned the role of linear order, namely whether information introduced later in the same sentence could establish preceding presupposed information as taken for granted. Our results suggest a negative answer to this theoretically important question, as linear order is key for interpreting presuppositions, at least in the context of conjunctive ‘and’.

The project has made educational contributions through the interdisciplinary work it engaged project personnel in. The postdoctoral researcher on the grant, who joined the project with a primarily theoretical background, has become a fully trained experimentalist with the interdisciplinary expertise that is needed for the ongoing integration of theoretical and experimental approaches in the study of meaning. He has also spearheaded a lasting methodological contribution by developing a software library for IBEX, a free platform for web-based experiments, which makes it easier to efficiently collect experimental data online, using a variety of stimuli (e.g., audio and images). In addition, 7 PhD students worked on the project over the course of the grant, developing their own related research and their skills for doing experimental research on meaning. Finally, 6 undergraduate research assistants helped to prepare experimental stimuli and collect data, acquiring methodological skills, e.g., how to use an eye tracker, and research experience.

The project has also contributed other results with broader relevance. As part of the central efforts to understand the cognitive processing of subtly different aspects of meaning, we conducted studies on presuppositions and certain pragmatic inferences, so-called implicatures, in patients suffering from Broca’s Aphasia. Expanding on the understanding of linguistic skills and challenges in this population, previously investigated with regards to syntactic sentence structures, we found their linguistic response behavior to be on par with unimpaired adult controls for the pragmatic inferences, but more similar to data from young children with regards to implicatures. We also looked at the interpretation of presuppositions associated with pronouns in Thai, comparing children diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and typically developing children, again contributing to the understanding of linguistic abilities of individuals with language-related impairments. Children with ASD exhibit greater difficulties with presuppositional inferences that require reasoning relative to the meanings of other expressions. Finally, another study investigated the impact of access to the verbatim wording of an utterance on the assessment of common pragmatic inferences, and found that verbatim access led to a greater propensity for resorting to literal, non-pragmatic interpretations; this is of high relevance for various real-world settings, e.g., for courtroom juries who often have to assess conversational evidence but have to rely on written transcripts of verbal exchanges in doing so.
